chapter.title: Getting started
chapter.para:
The first thing to do if you want to help out hacking on Planner is to join the Planner-devel mailing list. List information can be found at:
http://lists.codefactory.se/mailman/listinfo/planner-devel .
Then read through this document to learn how we work and the coding style rules that should be used in Planner code. Finally, please join us for discussions in #planner at Gimpnet (irc.gnome.org).

sect1.title: Getting the source
sect1.para:
When developing on Planner we strongly recommend using the source from CVS. If you have a CVS account at cvs.gnome.org you get the source code by:
# export CVSROOT=":pserver:yourlogin@cvs.gnome.org:/cvs/gnome" # cvs co libplanner # cvs co planner Otherwise you can download it from our anonymous cvs with the following commands.
# export CVSROOT=":pserver:anonymous@anoncvs.gnome.org:/cvs/gnome" # cvs login
(No password, just press enter.)
# cvs -z3 co libplanner # cvs -z3 co planner

sect1.title: Building the source
sect1.para:
To build Planner you need to first build libplanner. Just execute the following commands.
# cd libplanner # ./autogen.sh --prefix=/prefix # make # make install Then you can build Planner by the following set of commands.
# cd planner # ./autogen.sh --prefix=/prefix # make # make install

sect1.title: Creating patches
sect1.para:
The easiest way to create patches is by using CVS. Before you make the patch, make sure that you have the latest changes from the CVS by executing:
# cvs up -Pd Then you can create the patch with:
# cvs diff -u > file.patch Make sure you use the -u flag, that makes the patch easier to read.

sect1.title: Submitting your patches
sect1.para:
Submitting patches can either be done by sending them to the planner-devel mailing list. Or by adding them as attachments to the issue the patch solves at the bugzilla at:
http://freedom.codefactory.se/bugzilla/ .

chapter.title: Programming Guidelines
chapter.para: This chapter discuss the coding guide lines that should be used in all Planner code. Please notice that if your code doesn't follow these guide lines it won't be included in Planner, therefor please make sure that it does before sending the patches.

sect1.title: Naming conventions
sect1.para: The naming schemes is a little different between libplanner and planner, this is to make it clear by looking at a function name to see where it belongs. The reason for a naming scheme is that it should be easy to find the definition and implementation of a function/enum/class/... by just looking at the name of it.

listitem.para: Classes should be named with a prefix Mrp for classes in libplanner and Planner for classes in planner.
Use upper case letters as word separators, lower case for the rest of the word.

sect2.title: File Names
sect2.para:
File names should be named as follows:
No upper case letters.
Use a hyphen ("-") to separate words.
Prefix filenames with mrp- for files in libplanner and planner- for files in planner.
Filenames
mrp-task-manager.c mrp-task-manager.h planner-resource-model.c planner-resource-model.h

sect2.title: External Functions Names
sect2.para:
External functions should be named as the file names with every hyphen ("-") replaced by an underscore ("_").
External function names
mrp_task_manager_get_root (...) planner_resource_model_get_type_string (...)

sect2.title: Static Functions Names
sect2.para:
This use the same scheme as external functions names but remove the prefix. So for example:
Static Functions Names
An external function
mrp_resource_get_name (...) would become
resource_get_name (...) if it was a static function withing mrp-resource.c.

para.emphasis: Notice that this scheme is currently not used in Planner but we'll change to it whenever we are editing those files, please use this scheme for all new code.

sect2.title: Enum/Struct Names
#define and Macro Names
sect2.para:
#defines and macros should be named in the same way as functions but with uppercase letters instead of lowercase.
#define and macro names
In mrp-resource.h
#define MRP_TYPE_RESOURCE (mrp_resource_get_type ()) In planner-resource-model.h
#define PLANNER_IS_RESOURCE_MODEL(obj) (G_TYPE_CHECK_INSTANCE_TYPE ((obj), PLANNER_TYPE_RESOURCE_MODEL))

sect1.title: Code Formatting
sect1.para: In order to make the code more readable we here define a number of formatting rules that has to be followed. If everyone hacking on Planner uses the same code formatting it will be much easier to read other persons code.

sect2.title: Indentation
Function declarations and implementation
Variable definitions
sect2.para: Variables should be aligned in the same way as function arguments. Put one space between longest type and arguments and align with * and ** in the same way as for function arguments.
